column3: talking to somebody who really takes a sensible view about this man Glossop. Mother says he's a good chap
column4: which is simply absurd. Anybody can see that he's absolutely impossible. He's conceited and opinionative and argues all the time
column5: even when he knows perfectly well that he's talking through his hat
column6: and he smokes too much and eats too much and drinks too much
column7: and I don't like the colour of his hair. Not that he'll have any hair in a year or two
column8: because he's pretty thin on the top already
column9: and before he knows where he is he'll be as bald as an egg
column10: and he's the last man who can afford to go bald. And I think it's simply disgusting
column11: the way he gorges all the time. Do you know
column12: I found him in the larder at one o'clock this morning
column13: absolutely wallowing in a steak-and-kidney pie? There was hardly any of it left. And you remember what an enormous dinner he had. Quite disgusting
column14: I call it. But I can't stop out here all night
column15: talking about men who aren't worth wasting a word on and haven't even enough sense to tell sharks from flatfish. I'm going in."""|"Right Ho

column1: 12:30|"12.30 p.m."|"I confess that the recollection of what this bell could do when it buckled down to it gave me pause as I stood that night at 12.30 p.m. prompt beside the outhouse where it was located. The sight of the rope against the whitewashed wall and the thought of the bloodsome uproar which was about to smash the peace of the night into hash served to deepen that rummy feeling to which I have alluded."|"Right Ho
ap 08:00|"eight o'clock"|"""Curse all dancing chauffeurs! What on earth does a chauffeur want to dance for? I mistrusted that man from the start. Something told me he was a dancer. Well
column2: this finishes it. We're out here till breakfast-time. If those blasted servants come back before eight o'clock
column3: I shall be vastly surprised. You won't get Seppings away from a dance till you throw him out. I know him. The jazz'll go to his head
column4: and he'll stand clapping and demanding encores till his hands blister. Damn all dancing butlers! What is Brinkley Court? A respectable English country house or a crimson dancing school? One might as well be living in the middle of the Russian Ballet. Well
column5: all right. If we must stay out here
column6: we must. We shall all be frozen stiff
column7: except""--here she directed at me not one of her friendliest glances----""except dear old Attila
